-->

#### Prerequisites checklist

#### What is the purpose of this pull request? (put an "X" next to an item)

<!--
    The following template is intentionally not a markdown checkbox list for the reasons
    explained in https://github.com/eslint/eslint/pull/12848#issuecomment-580302888
-->

[ ] Documentation update
[ ] Bug fix ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/bug-report.md))
[ ] New rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/rule-proposal.md))

[ ] Add autofix to a rule
[ ] Add a CLI option
[ ] Add something to the core
[x] Other, please explain:

Refs https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/16264. Removes everything mentioned except for the `ignorePatterns` constructor option. I can do that in a separate PR when we are certain that the option should be removed.

<!--
    If the item you've checked above has a template, please paste the template questions below and answer them. (If this pull request is addressing an issue, you can just paste a link to the issue here instead.)
-->

<!--
    Please ensure your pull request is ready:

    - Read the pull request guide (https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/pull-requests)
    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

<!--
    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

#### What changes did you make? (Give an overview)

- Removed all support for separate ignore files.
    - Removed loading `.eslintignore` files.
    - Removed `ignorePath` constructor option.
    - Removed `--ignore-path` CLI option.
 - Removed interpreting `--ignore-patterns` and `ignorePatterns` as .gitignore-style patterns.

#### Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?

<!-- markdownlint-disable-file MD004 -->

body:
I've been investigating other options besides `globby` and there doesn't appear to be another option that supports everything we need.

I'm now looking at the easiest way to replace `globby` that doesn't require that much code added into ESLint.

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

issue.body:
Removes globby due to numerous issues with ignoring files and returning the correct files.

Fixes #16354
Fixes #16340
Fixes #16300

<!--
    Thank you for contributing!

    ESLint adheres to the [JS Foundation Code of Conduct](https://eslint.org/conduct).
-->

#### Prerequisites checklist

- [x] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md).

#### What is the purpose of this pull request? (put an "X" next to an item)

<!--
    The following template is intentionally not a markdown checkbox list for the reasons
    explained in https://github.com/eslint/eslint/pull/12848#issuecomment-580302888
-->

[ ] Documentation update
[ ] Bug fix ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/bug-report.md))
[ ] New rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/rule-proposal.md))
[ ] Changes an existing rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/rule-change-proposal.md))
[ ] Add autofix to a rule
[ ] Add a CLI option
[x] Add something to the core
[ ] Other, please explain:

<!--
    If the item you've checked above has a template, please paste the template questions below and answer them. (If this pull request is addressing an issue, you can just paste a link to the issue here instead.)
-->

<!--
    Please ensure your pull request is ready:

    - Read the pull request guide (https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/pull-requests)
    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

<!--
    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

#### What changes did you make? (Give an overview)

I removed `globby` and replaced it with a custom solution built upon `@nodelib/fs.walk`, which was used by `fast-glob` to walk the directory and look for matching filenames. Instead of forcing `globby` to reinterpret ignores, this solution uses `FlatConfigArray#isFileIgnored()` as part of the traversal so it exactly mirrors the ignoring behavior inside of a config array. This should fix a lot of the outstanding issues related to ignoring certain files.

#### Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?

If you've seen weird behavior, please check out this branch and try it out to see if it fixes the issue. I'm still adding tests to this PR to make sure everything is fixed.

Also, I marked as "feat" because it seemed worthy of a minor release, but totally fine to mark as "fix" if others feel differently.

<!-- markdownlint-disable-file MD004 -->

body:
> Since config `ignores` patterns match files (not directories), the `foo/bar/a.js` file should be linted.

This is an incorrect assumption. `ignores` in config files will match both directories and files, just like `.eslintignore` or `.gitignore`. So `foo/bar` tells ESLint "do not traverse into directory foo/bar," meaning that `foo/bar/a.js` should be ignored. Using `foo/bar/**` would allow the traversal to go into the directory and would also ignore `foo/bar/a.js`.

I agree that there is a bug here and that the bug is that all three commands should work the same. However, I believe they should all actually not match any files because an ignored directory will not be traversed into.

My assumption was based on the behavior of FlatConfigArray at the time. But I don't think there's a standard on how ignoring with minimatch patterns should work (especially if negative patterns are allowed), so I believe we can design it however we think it would be best. Resembling .gitignore-style where patterns match both directories and files, and there's a rule that all files under an ignored directory are ignored, seems best for performance and will probably meet common expectations.

> `ignores` in config files will match both directories and files, just like `.eslintignore` or `.gitignore`. So `foo/bar` tells ESLint "do not traverse into directory foo/bar," meaning that `foo/bar/a.js` should be ignored. Using `foo/bar/**` would allow the traversal to go into the directory and would also ignore `foo/bar/a.js`.
> 
> I agree that there is a bug here and that the bug is that all three commands should work the same. However, I believe they should all actually not match any files because an ignored directory will not be traversed into.

:+1:

> Resembling .gitignore-style where patterns match both directories and files, and there's a rule that all files under an ignored directory are ignored, seems best for performance and will probably meet common expectations.

Yes, this was always the intent, but things got weird when using `globby`. It is much easier to make this work without `globby`.
